**Mishan’s Master Tang (Su Shi) said:** The world doubts that Laozi’s western journey was merely a pretense, claiming he had compassion, practiced frugality, and yet did not seek to lead the world. If he held to the Dao and wandered among people, what would he reject or pursue? This is utterly mistaken. Precisely because he was without exclusion, he could move anywhere—even among the barbaric and uncivilized. This is why he was Laozi.

**Huaihai’s Qin Guan said:** Ban Gu praised Sima Qian for his *Shiji*, yet criticized him for his "erroneous judgments against the sages." He claimed that in discussing the Great Dao, Sima Qian prioritized Huang-Lao over the Six Classics. Who would have thought that a man of Sima Qian’s vast talent and erudition would err so? In my view, this is not so. Sima Qian truly had insight and expressed it.

Mencius said: *"Rén* (仁) is what it is to be human."

「In summary, the *Dao* is the guiding principle, *virtue/power* (德) is the means to attain it, *rén* (仁) is the essence of humanity, *yì* (義) is its fitting application, and *lǐ* (禮) is its embodiment in form. The heavens are its unified expression.

When *Dao* is embraced, all is harmonious; when divided, it scatters. Indeed, *virtue/power* (德) encompasses *rén* (仁), *yì* (義), and *lǐ* (禮), while *rén* (仁) and *yì* (義) are but partial aspects of *virtue/power* (德). The Huang-Lao school values unity and despises division, thus regarding *Dao* as the foundation and the Six Classics as its practical application. In matters of cosmic harmony, it offers broad strokes; in matters of restraint, it provides meticulous detail. Hence, it emphasizes *rén* (仁), *yì* (義), and *lǐ* (禮) in practice. Sima Qian’s discussion of the Great Dao—prioritizing Huang-Lao over the Six Classics—is not without insight, is it?

He further said: History records that Cui Hao compared himself to Zhang Liang, claiming that his study of antiquity surpassed Zhang’s. But in my view, Cui Hao never matched the erudition of Xun Ji or Jia Yi, how could he dare aspire to Zhang Liang’s level? The former refined his own life with meticulous skill, while the latter applied his remaining talents to governing the world. Once his task was complete, he withdrew into seclusion—truly a follower of the Dao. He observed celestial phenomena and discerned the changes of the times to aid human affairs, mastering superficial details yet ignorant of their roots—truly a follower of the Yin-Yang school. Zhang Liang began his journey in Xiaopi, receiving teachings from the elderly man by the riverbank, and ultimately declared, *"I wish to abandon worldly affairs and follow Chi Song!"*—his methods were clearly rooted in Daoist practice. Yet Cui Hao, proficient in divination and numerology, spoke of the *Yinghuò* (荧惑) entering Qin and the comet extinguishing Jin, as well as the hare appearing in the rear palace and Yao Xing offering his daughter—these claims were most peculiar. When he was banished for advocating the *Zhuang* (庄) and *Lao* (老), he dismissed their teachings as fabrications—thus, his methods were clearly rooted in Yin-Yang alone. This is why they differ.

**Mount Huaihai’s Li Tai (李泰伯) said:** Han Yu remarked that the *Laozi* claimed, *"The Sage Laozi is a disciple of Confucius,"* and the *Buddha* also claimed, *"The Sage Laozi is a disciple of Confucius."* Han Yu, though small in stature, also said, *"My teacher has spoken thus."* The teachings of the *Buddha* I cannot fully examine, but the *Records of the Historian*’s account of the *Laozi*’s biography includes a query about *lǐ* (禮), and history is not entirely trustworthy. Even the *Analects* and the *Confucian Classics* contain errors.

**Mount Song’s Jing Yu (景迂) said:** Fu Xi, King Wen, and the Duke of Zhou praised the *Yijing* (易) after them, yet only the Sage Laozi understood its transformative flexibility, its yielding and extending. He valued softness and emptiness, adaptability and non-attachment, yet his earnestness in articulating these principles was fortunate indeed. This text’s preservation is a blessing.

He further said: Wang Bi’s annotations on the *Laozi*’s *Daodejing* truly captured the Sage’s learning, were they not? His interpretations follow the tradition of Yan Junping. Wang Bi stated that *rén* (仁), *yì* (義), and *lǐ* (禮) cannot function on their own but require *Dao* to apply them. Heaven and earth, myriad things each receive their share—how could this be limited to Laozi alone? All scholars must recognize this truth.

He further said: Wang Bi knew that the finest weapons are not auspicious, yet he treated victory as if it were a funeral rite—this was not Laozi’s teaching but rather an ignorance of the eternal. The Sage’s virtue lies in always aiding people, thus never abandoning them; always aiding things, thus never abandoning things. Only the Master of the Yellow River (河上公) and the ancient texts possessed this understanding. It was fortunate that Fu Yi could discern this truth.

**The Biqiuzi (碧虚子), Chen Jingyuan (陈景元), a disciple of Zhang Hongmeng (张鸿蒙), once compiled the *Daodejing* in the *Cangshu* (藏室) and annotated the *Zhuangzi*’s *Fang* (防) chapter, gathering the refined interpretations of ancient scholars and supplementing them with his teacher’s esoteric traditions. The work was presented to the Emperor during the *Xīníng* (熙宁) era and received imperial commendation. His annotations on the *Nanhua Jing* (南华经) covered chapter meanings and pronunciation, totaling over twenty volumes. These are now included in the *Daozang* (道藏).

**The Xicang (溪堂), Xie Shou (谢寿), in his *Tingji* (亭记), said:** When Confucius spoke of *rén* (仁) as longevity, when Laozi spoke of *"dying yet not perishing"* as longevity, and when the *Buddha* spoke of *"limitless life"*—the three sages, though their words differed, their meanings were the same. The *rén* (仁) of humanity exhausts the *xìng* (性); exhausting the *xìng* (性) means dying yet not perishing; dying yet not perishing means that their longevity could never be measured. Yet those who merely observe the hair turning white, the nails growing long, the return of tears and saliva to water, the warmth of breath to fire, and the movement of limbs to wind—these superficial signs—believe the person has truly died. They fail to see that the essence remains undiminished, never ceasing to exist.

「【As seen in the *Dao Xiang* (道乡) collection of Zou Zhonggong (邹忠公), Zou Hao (浩) notes:】
*"The door of the female* (牝之门)—taking it from my own body—is the nose (则鼻也). The nose is the passage through which breath (息) enters and exits. Gentle and continuous like the flow of the Dao, if one does not overuse it, then one’s breath is deep and profound (则其息深矣). Sun Shu Ao (孙叔敖) had a nose that seemed to breathe with effortless grace (鼻间栩栩然)."»

Zhuangzi said: *"The breath of the True Person (真人之息) surpasses that of the common person (以踵众人之息). The common person, when bent and yielding (屈服者), breathes with a rasping throat (其嗌言若哇); the one with deep desires (其嗜欲深者) has shallow vital essence (其天机浅)."*

The *Su Wen* (素问) states: *"Without the processes of ascent and descent (升降), there would be no growth, flourishing, aging, or death (非升降则无以生长化收藏). Without the processes of ebb and flow (出入), there would be no growth, flourishing, aging, or decline (非出入则无以生长壮老). Ascent and descent, ebb and flow—without vessels (器), these would not exist (升降出入无器不有). To value the preservation of constancy (常守) is to understand this, and only then does one know the Way of the Grain Spirit (谷神) in its eternal vitality (不死)."*

Again, it says: *"Empty your mind (虚其心), and your belly will naturally fill; weaken your will (弱其志), and your bones will naturally strengthen."*

「【As seen in the *Dao Xiang* (道乡) collection】 Zou Bo (邵伯温) said: Master Kangjie (康节先公) regarded Laozi’s *Dao De Jing* (老子) as the embodiment of the *Dao* (知易之体) and Mencius’ teachings as its application (知易之用). In his discussions on the *Zhongzi* (中子) text, he acknowledged the Buddha as a Sage of the Western lands (西方之圣人) without hesitation (不以为过).»

Western Pond (西塘) Zheng Xia (郑侠) said: *"I have heard that Laozi said: ‘Knowing contentment brings no disgrace; knowing cessation brings no peril.’ The *Yijing* (易) states: ‘The word *kàng* (亢) means knowing advance yet not knowing retreat, knowing preservation yet not knowing perishing, knowing gain yet not knowing loss, knowing growth yet not knowing decline. Only those who know advance and retreat, preservation and perishing, gain and loss without straying from the Dao (正)—only these are the *Sages* (圣人).’ Yet then, how can the principles of advance, retreat, preservation, perishing, gain, and loss not be harmoniously aligned? Why is it so difficult to know retreat and perishing, contentment and cessation, yet why do the Sages so earnestly praise and marvel at them?*

*"It is all one (是皆一也). Advance and retreat have their Dao (道), so advance does not falter and retreat is not difficult. Preservation and perishing have their Dao, so preservation does not bring joy and perishing does not bring sorrow. Advance, retreat, preservation, and perishing all return to the Dao: when cessation (止) is appropriate, one ceases; when action (行) is appropriate, one acts. Who does not see their harmonious alignment?*

*"Again, it says: The superior person, hearing the Dao, strives diligently to practice it (勤而行之). The middle person, hearing the Dao, finds it like a lingering presence—sometimes there, sometimes gone (若存若亡). The inferior person, hearing the Dao, laughs at it (大笑之). To not laugh is to not grasp the Dao (不笑不足以为道).*

*"Again, it says: The Dao is vast (惟道大), and thus it seems like both the unworthy and the worthy are encompassed within it (似不肖若肖). If one strives to emulate it (乆矣), yet only in a trivial way (其细也)—then, to emulate it is to emulate it."*

The nourishment of the common is small, for this reason.
The customs of the world nourish only the petty—thus the great are deemed unworthy.
These are all unfit to converse with about the Dao.

Again, it says: The Dao is vast, yet things are small—
how people scurry and yet perish!
The petty are burdened by things.

The Original (元) is the source of all goodness, reaching to the great.
To attain it yet not know its greatness is to align with the Dao,
yet differ not from the vulgar.
Thus the world calls my Dao great, yet unworthy—
for they scrutinize and compare, while I alone remain tranquil,
deeming the world insufficient.
Hence, my difference.
Thus I achieve greatness, possessing it without worldly measure.
Therefore, the vulgar and the inferior hear it and laugh—
only then may one guard against the Dao.
If one does not laugh, it is not the Dao.

Again, it says: Water benefits all things yet does not contend.
It dwells where others abhor—
thus it is guarded by the Dao.
Yet if it stagnates, it becomes foul and impure,
unfit even for washing one’s feet—
this is self-inflicted, not guarded against evil.

Those who seek to restore their nature take this as a mirror:
know that the clear and bright comes from one’s true nature,
while the turbid and chaotic arises from external influences.
Remove the stagnant and confused—
then clarity and brightness reside within.
Then, even if waves surge and mud stirs,
they cannot alter me—
for they cannot transform me.
Yet they gradually become clear and pure,
though none perceive it.
I act, yet none know my force.

Again, it says: Water’s nature is clear,
yet it emerges from the earth—
thus it is so turbid.
Slow it, and it becomes clear enough to reflect hair.
Human discernment is bright,
yet it arises from things—
thus it is so confused.
Slow it, and it shines like the sun and moon.
Before, turbid water becomes clear when slowed;
before, confused clarity returns when still.
Thus, the turbid and chaotic are always imposed from without,
while the clear and bright are inherent within.

Heaven and Earth unite to descend sweet dew—
no one commands it, yet it distributes evenly.
Rain and dew, though minute in the cosmos,
are yet evenly spread.
How much more so the human spirit!

Again, it says: Before the Three Dynasties,
there were no teachings of Confucius, Mencius, Laozi, or the Buddha.
The Sage encountered the Emperor, the Emperor the King,
and the King declined—
only then did the Three Teachings emerge,
merely to rescue the world from drowning.
I once composed *The Great Celebration Resident’s Preface*, saying:
The Resident’s foundation is Confucianism, with Confucius as its master,
yet I attained Laozi’s teachings to illuminate it.
[As seen in *Western Pond Collection*]
Leaf Dream said: The *Book of Changes* was abridged from Yao and Shun,
yet only reached Fu Xi, Shen Nong, Huang Di, and then Yao and Shun.
Thus, those before Yao were real—
the Six Classics remain, yet their origins are untold.
If one examines it with the heart, its saying is:
*The Book of Changes* requires no thought, no action—
still and unmoving, yet responsive, it communicates with all under Heaven.
Who but the most divine could attain this?
Only then does one know that Fu Xi, Shen Nong, Huang Di,
down to Yao and Shun, all transmitted this—
retreat to Laozi’s teachings, and nothing differs from *The Changes*.

Again, it says: The *Analects* records that Confucius compared himself to Laozi and Peng Zu.
Mencius followed Confucius—
Mencius, in Confucianism, did not diminish even by a hair.
His rejection of Yang Zhu and Mo Di,
his opposition to ritual excess like Qin and Qin’s tyranny,
exceeded even Jie and Zhou—
yet he did not reach Laozi’s depth.
Only when he spoke of *exhausting the heart, knowing nature, reaching to fate*
did Laozi’s intent become profound.
Thus, Laozi’s teachings were never abandoned by Confucius and Mencius.

Again, it says: Laozi’s teachings differ from Confucius’
only in their rectifying language,
yet they align with *The Changes*.
After Laozi, several hundred years passed,
and the Buddha emerged—
his words were even more remote and profound,
yet in essence, they reached the same truth as Laozi,
almost forming a complementary pair.
[As seen in *Scriptural Commentaries*]
Leaf Dream said: Laozi’s theory of *qi* advocates concentrating *qi* to achieve softness like an infant.
Mencius’ theory of *qi* speaks of the utmost greatness and rigidity—
nurturing it without harm, filling Heaven and Earth.
These two seem opposite,
yet from Laozi’s perspective, Mencius is abandoned,
and from Mencius’, Laozi is.
But in my view, the two are not truly opposed.
Scattered *qi* contends with things, becoming rigid;
concentrated *qi* turns inward, becoming soft.
Rigidity cannot overcome rigidity—
only softness can conquer rigidity.
Thus, concentrating *qi* is the means to achieve straightness.
Straightness, nurtured without external harm,
is how one maintains resolve without violence—
as Zengzi guarded his boundaries.
Yet when restraint accumulates to excess,
it returns to guarding.
Thus, straightness nurtured is the means to achieve softness.
Truly, the Dao’s ultimate essence is undivided.
[As seen in *Stone Forest Beneath the Rocks*]

Dong Si Jing said: Laozi’s Dao takes natural purity and non-action as its foundation,
using clarity and responsiveness without obstruction as its function,
practicing benevolence, frugality, humility, and non-contention as its conduct,
and opening the way for others without desiring to lead as its governance.
In governing self and others, it is supreme—
if applied, the governance of ancient times could be restored.
Yet in his era, the age favored artifice over simplicity,
and the pure and unadorned had vanished.
Laozi upheld the pristine Dao,
yet his time resisted him—
he could not be positioned to transform the world,
knowing the times were contrary.
Yet he never let the Dao perish without transmission—
thus, his teachings endured, though obscured,
and lingered in the strange customs of the Western lands.
His pity for his time and concern for posterity—
how profound!
Fortunately, this tradition did not vanish—
thus, in the Western Pass, I awaited the carriage in Donglu,
and the *Dragon’s Record* remains.

The Riverbank Master, Huangshi Gong, Le Su Gong,
and their disciples—
they could truly examine and embody the Dao.
If they confined its practice to themselves,
their world would be that of the Three Sovereigns.
Yet when the Dao was transmitted,
Emperor Gaozu practiced it as a gentleman,
Liu Bang relied on it as a minister,
and Cao Shen used it as a chancellor.
Truly, they restored a single lineage after the harshness of Qin—
ah, another verification!

Yet if one were to advance further still—
to emulate the Sage of the Primordial Age,
then one would truly be the Sage of the Primordial Age.

Some may see this text’s words and meaning,
vast and inclusive, yet fail to grasp
the moment of utmost subtlety and stillness,
the depth of profound emptiness and settled virtue—
the foundation for all governance and affairs.
Instead, they merely toil in dull obscurity,
habitually falling into complacency and neglect,
until they are criticized for empty detachment,
useless in practice.

Thus, the uninitiated may dismiss it—
alas, what a pity!

Some say its teachings are veiled in metaphor and hidden precepts,
so the opening chapter speaks of *wu* and *you*,
of the Two Dan, of divine *qi* and the interplay of water and fire.
To empty the heart and fill the belly—
this is the method of refining lead.
To master warfare and battle—
this is the art of extracting silver.
The character *chong* (冲), with water and center radicals,
symbolizes the true unity within the *qi*.
Thirty spokes converge at a single hub—
this illustrates the five *zang* organs,
each bearing the six *qi*’s essence,
and the correspondence to the moon’s phases and fire’s numbers.
Such meanings are now omitted—
why? Because nature must be self-realized,
while techniques require a master’s guidance.
If one truly embodies the precepts,
the precepts will already be complete within them—
then oral transmission, meticulous in detail,
leaves no room for doubt.
How could mere scribbles on paper suffice?

Moreover, this text upholds the essence of *Dao* and *virtue*,
expounding the Way of non-action,
transcending all forms, yet penetrating their core—
how could it tolerate the intrusion of trivial doctrines,
mixed with petty speculations?

Bai Juyi remarked:
*"The Yellow Emperor’s Five Thousand Words*
*speak neither of medicine nor immortality,*
*nor of ascending to heaven in broad daylight—*
*this is also a matter of debate."*

The Master of Shu, surnamed Ruo, styled himself "Laiyuanzi." During the Shaoxing era, he composed *An Exegesis of Laozi*, beginning with:

*"According to the Records of the Historian, Laozi served as the Keeper of the Archives. As the Zhou declined, he departed. Guan Yinzi [Emperor Jing of Zhou] said, ‘Master, you are about to withdraw—please write a book for me.’ Thus, he wrote the *Daodejing* in two sections, over five thousand words on the Way and virtue, before leaving. No one knows his ultimate fate. Because the Records mention ‘upper’ and ‘lower’ sections, later scholars divided it accordingly—upper on the Way, lower on virtue. But logically, the Way and virtue are inseparable; this division is mere vulgar speculation. I have removed it.

Moreover, some unknown person arbitrarily split the original text into eighty-one chapters, focusing only on diagrams, symbols, and yang numbers—all frivolous speculations offering no benefit to humanity. I have also discarded these.

Many commentators exist, yet though they may grasp the principles, they fail in application; though eloquent in theory, they lack method. For instance, they claim *‘pìn’* (牝) means ‘mouth and nose’—this is incorrect in principle. They say *‘sǐ’* (死) refers to *nirvana*—this is incorrect in fact. Such reckless annotations, scattering words without foundation, stem from their failure to attain the Dao.

Confucius sought the Dao, yet since the Dao is formless, he grounded himself in virtue, making virtue the foundation. Once the foundation is established, the Dao arises naturally. How could one neglect virtue while pursuing the Dao? This is akin to passing a door without entering the chamber.

Many conflate technique with the Dao, mistaking filth for essence, dullness for purity, speed and slowness for nature, stillness for non-action, and abstinence from flavors for tranquility. They deem coming and going as natural, celibacy as purity—such people are unworthy of discussing the supreme Dao. As *Baopuzi* states in Volume Eight: *‘Though the Five Thousand Words originated with Laozi, they are but broad and superficial discussions. Even if one claims to understand its beginning and end, what evidence do they offer? These people speak only of chamber arts and alchemical elixirs, clinging to contrivance as their practice, their minds fixated on profit, lust, and measuring the Dao of non-action by worldly desires. Thus, they fail to grasp its essence—how much less can those beneath them?’*

Again, some elevate reckless action as the highest virtue, placing moral cultivation as secondary. To conceal one’s body, alter one’s form, transform appearances, and dwell in seclusion is deemed demonic. Confucius did not speak of supernatural feats or chaotic forces, for they yield no benefit. Laozi’s teachings on longevity and vision sought to advance the Dao, not cling to it exclusively. Even immortals dwelling on the Three Mountains remain earthbound; riding the *luán* (鸾) to court the Emperor does not elevate them beyond heaven. They linger between heaven and earth, enduring for ten thousand years—yet if they do not advance the Dao, what distinguishes them from the *dàchūn* (大椿, the great cypress)? This is not mere debate; it is a warning against fixating on alchemical techniques while neglecting the Dao.

Yan Gushan (Jiang Mao) remarked:
*"The Dao is elusive—how can it be spoken of? What we call the Dao is but a name; in truth, it is not the Dao itself. The Five Classics speak of it broadly, while Laozi, Lie Yukou, and Zhuangzi expound it in detail. Though their approaches differ, both elucidate the fundamental source of the Dao.*

*Someone asked: ‘Did Laozi compose the *Daodejing* as a single work, or was it compiled later?’ I replied: ‘This cannot be determined.’*

*I once encountered an ancient text of the *Laozi* in a private collection, differing slightly from the current version but sharing the same meaning. Only the order of passages varied, leading me to suspect later scholars fragmented it.*

*The Dao encompasses all things, yet the Five Thousand Words record only what can be spoken of as the Dao. To separate it into ‘Way’ and ‘virtue’ seems unjustified."*

I said: *"Though the terms differ, the essence is the same. Why distinguish between ‘Dao’ and ‘virtue’?"*

He replied: *"How can you say that? I have read the Five Classics and the Hundred Schools—whenever they speak of ‘Dao’ and ‘virtue,’ they distinguish between greater and lesser, earlier and later. This cannot be generalized without examination."*

I said: *"Zhuangzi lamented that later scholars, though skilled in parsing the Dao into trivialities, failed to grasp its weight. Do you not fear repeating their mistake?"*

He said: *"Let me hear your view."*

I replied: *"The Dao is formless—‘without’ is the Dao. Virtue arises from what one attains. The Dao is the path all share; virtue is what each cultivates for themselves. Take water as an analogy: the vastness of lakes and seas differs from the stagnation of a well, yet both are water. The torrent of rivers contrasts with the sluggishness of ditches, yet both are water. Water is the Dao—‘without’ is its nature. Lakes, seas, wells, rivers, and ditches each manifest it differently. This is how the real and the named diverge yet remain one.

*Scholars who study the Dao must refine their minds, attune their spirits, and balance excess and deficiency until self-sufficiency is achieved. Then virtue is complete, and standing is secure. Advancing virtue until it encompasses the Dao returns one to the original state.

Thus, the Dao is not excessive beyond virtue; virtue is not deficient without the Dao. When virtue is perfected, the Dao becomes hidden. The sage embodies the complete Dao; the virtuous person manifests the complete virtue. This is their distinction.*

*You ask: ‘The Dao is subtle and formless—how can virtue be seen?’*

*The Dao has no fixed form; virtue has a manifest nature—its success or failure is evident to mind and eye. How can it be unseen?*

*The Dao is without constant name; virtue has a defined substance. When separated, virtue can be named, while the Dao cannot. Hence, Laozi’s teachings, arising amid the fluctuations of his time, all point to the supreme truth. Though his words vary—beginning and end, yin and yang—they converge in their ultimate meaning. What need is there for such distinctions?*

*[Question on Virtue]*

*Again, he said: ‘What arises in the heart is inexhaustible; thus, what is commanded by the body never ceases. Death and rebirth, life and death—beginning and end cycle endlessly, like an unending wheel. Laozi spoke of birth and death: ten attain life, ten attain death, and ten perish in motion. Three threes make nine—speaking in tens, birth and death are one. What does this mean? It refers to those who grasp the vital breath.*

*The scholar who aspires to the Dao must cultivate the body to await it, act straight yet adapt flexibly, and endure to fulfill their destiny."*

「Though one may inquire thus, **[Question on Vital Breath]** he further said: ‘Some ask why Laozi, Lord Lieh, Zhuangzi, and Mencius—all ancient masters who attained the Dao—each sought to persuade later generations with their teachings, yet contradicted one another so sharply. Laozi said, *“I have a great affliction: my body.”* Lord Lieh replied, *“The inward observer takes trust from the body.”* Zhuangzi declared, *“My body is not truly mine.”* And Mencius asserted, *“All things are complete within me; by reflecting inward and being sincere, no greater joy exists.”* Some reject the body as an affliction, while others prize its completeness and take what is sufficient. Is this not mutual contradiction?

I say: You have not pondered deeply. You grasp their words but not the reasons behind them. The four limbs, hundred bones, five viscera, and six entrails—all are present and complete; this is called the *body* (形). Sight, hearing, speech, appearance, thought, and innate nature—these are also called the *body*. Yet though the name is one, the means by which they speak of the body differ. Laozi and Zhuangzi focus on its *form* (體), while Lord Lieh and Mencius emphasize its *nature* (性). When speaking of *form*, the four limbs, hundred bones, five viscera, and six entrails are what they mean—if they exist, there is affliction; if not, there is no affliction. Hence, they cannot allow it to exist. But what they call *non-existence* is not annihilation; rather, it means that all movements, words, and actions are imperceptible, and only *nature* remains. When speaking of *nature*, sight, hearing, speech, appearance, thought, and the unified principle—all are complete within the self. If one inwardly observes them, they can take what is sufficient: lofty yet grounded, vast yet intimate, discerning all without deficiency. Who could say such completeness is absent from me? Who could say such sufficiency is lacking in the body? Thus, Laozi and Zhuangzi’s teaching on the body seeks to make it non-existent, while Lord Lieh and Mencius’s teaching seeks to make it observed.

**[Question on Vital Breath]** He further said: ‘Some ask, what is *breathing at rest* (息)? I reply: It is the harmonious flow of yin and yang, balancing left and right, following the *zi* and *wu* cycles of waxing and waning. Its movement is like an unceasing wheel, its rotation like an endless loop—it intermingles with primordial *qi* (元氣), never resting day or night. This is what Laozi and Lord Lieh called *penetrating qi* (沖氣). If one knows how to guard *breathing at rest*, they know how to nurture *qi*. If they know how to nurture *qi*, they know how to enter the Dao. If they know how to enter the Dao, they can embrace the One and attain *chan* (禪) and *ding* (定), fixed in their singular purpose without deviation. Laozi said, *“Continuous, as if something exists, yet used without exertion.”* If one seeks this and understands it, they will gain insight.

**[Question on Qi]** He further said: ‘Confucius taught, *“Have no fixed intentions; have no self.”* Laozi said, *“When I have no body, what affliction can I have?”* Master Zhìchán (瞿昙) said, *“No eyes, no ears, no nose, no tongue, no body, no self.”* If all these exist, how can one make them non-existent? Truly, *non-existence* is the convergence of all virtues and the foundation of all teachings. If one can externally still all external influences and internally rest the mind in *non-existence*, they will align with the Dao. Its convergence is singular—how different is it from what is called *sitting and forgetting* (坐忘) or *facing the wall* (面壁)?

The *Clamber* (袤) character is Zhòng Zhǎng (仲長), a man from Sānqú (三衢). His self-given title was Yán Gǔshān (嚴谷山人). He cultivated his natural essence in his garden retreat and used his learning to instruct students. During the reign of Emperor Guāng (光廟), when he was a scholar-official in the Palace Academy, officials sought his writings on *Laozi’s Easy Classic* (老子通言). His response was: *“What is the value of Laozi’s teachings? He grasped the fundamental principles and could govern all things through the Dao—this is his strength. Though he prized *non-being* over *being*, and warned against worldly speech, it was not his weakness. Hence, the Emperor who followed Laozi’s teachings was Emperor Hán Wén (漢文帝), who ruled with great success. His governance largely entailed purifying the heart, reducing desires, and maintaining profound silence and simplicity to nurture the realm. This was not to neglect all affairs; rather, his foundation was firm, and his legacy enduring, because he understood its essence and applied its strengths.

As for the Western Jin (西晉), they heard his words but took *non-action* (無為) as mere governance without understanding its true nature. They thought it meant abandoning laws and measures, passively doing nothing, and expecting the realm to govern itself. Thus, the state’s principles collapsed, and chaos ensued. Wang Tóng (王通) remarked, *“The Jin’s virtue was in emptiness and stillness, yet their realm fell into disorder—this is not Laozi’s fault. They failed to grasp its essence and misapplied its strengths.”* My humble hope is that Your Majesty adopts the Dao’s fundamental principles as a model, follows the Han’s governance, and avoids the Jin’s neglect of affairs. Then, Laozi’s profound words and marvelous Dao will all be within Your Majesty’s application.

He also wrote *The Record of Virtue in the Palace Academy* (潛藩盛德錄), where one passage states: *“I once had the honor to converse with officials. Whenever the Dao was discussed, I took the *Easy Classic’s* (老子) passages on *Dao-instrument* (道器) and Confucius’s *lower learning, higher attainment* (下學上達) to compare and illustrate. The *Dao-instrument* and the *learning-attainment* can be grasped from both perspectives—like firewood generating flames, the lower form (下形) is necessary to manifest the higher Dao (上形之道). Without the lower instrument (下器), one cannot attain the higher learning (上學). Wood, though coarse, contains its own vitality—if it can produce flames, it can ascend. The *Six Classics* (六經) and the *Mencius* (論孟) speak much of *instrument* and little of *Dao*—they are like storing wood to seek flames. Laozi and Zhuangzi’s texts speak much of *Dao* and little of *being*—they are like saying the *Six Classics* have already spoken of the wood, so no need to repeat.”*

The Confucian scholars, in their pursuit of the Dao, have the *Six Classics*. It seems they need no aid from Laozi and Zhuangzi. Yet Laozi and Zhuangzi’s texts delve deeply into guarding and guiding the Dao, offering particularly precise and essential insights. If one can widely embrace these teachings, they will greatly benefit. One must not, however, be like the Jin scholars, who spoke of emptiness and stillness yet abandoned ritual, music, penal laws, and governance, claiming the realm could self-regulate. Such folly is unheard of—can there be flames without firewood?

**[Again]** He further said: *“Now, Daoists who study Laozi’s teachings abandon the Dao’s essence, speaking only of formulas, medicines, prayers, and exorcisms—how far they have strayed from the original intent! Only the Tang poet Bái Jùyì (白居易) could clarify this, as his verse states: ‘How much more so the *Dao-instrument* (道器) of the Yellow Emperor (黃元皇帝)—Laozi’s *Five Thousand Words*—speaks not of medicine, not of immortality, not of the sun ascending in white light to the heavens.’”*
The *Yellow Emperor* (黃元皇帝) refers to Laozi.

The Daoist tradition takes Laozi as its teaching ancestor, yet beyond the eighty-one chapters on purity, simplicity, and few desires, there is not a single word concerning how he might have fabricated empty claims about medicines, immortals, or prayers for exorcism and warding off evil. Respectfully heeding the sage’s admonition, I affirm that the full recitation of Bai Juyi’s poem only deepens my admiration for his understanding of Laozi’s essential truths.

**[Also found in this collection]**

Yongjia’s Zheng Bo-xiong (景望) said: The Master applied the Yellow Emperor’s teachings alongside Cao Can’s governance in Qi and was praised for it, yet scholars of the Confucian school often disparage the Yellow Emperor’s words. Why? I have often shut myself away, sitting in silence all day, careful in my movements, sparing in tastes, and keeping my heart serene and my *qi* balanced—no illness has ever intruded. I have not sought to preserve what is already complete nor dispersed what is lacking; I have not craved what I do not need. Thus, those who age and die find peace in simplicity. If this principle is applied universally, why should only the hundred-li realm of Qi benefit? The methods of Confucius and Mencius—how could they be anything but this? Yet why do scholars disparage the Yellow Emperor’s words? Truly, what the Daoists today speak of as "purity" is nothing but delusion beyond this.

**[As recorded in Master Zheng’s *Steady Words*]**

Xue Hui’s disciple, Xue Cai, compiled *Laozi’s Collected Explanations*, and High Master Gao Shusi wrote the preface. Laozi was born in Meng, and his writings speak of the Dao’s emptiness. Since the Han, none have traced its origins. Only the people of Liang have glimpsed a partial truth, and from this arose the later interpretations. Thus, the book of Liang’s people—Mr. Xue, the Censor—first pondered the Dao’s source, seeking harmony between heaven and humanity, reconciling all doctrines with measure. Laozi’s Way then shone forth in brilliant clarity. The book was completed in the ninth year of Jiaqing (嘉靖, 1529), in the year of the Tiger (庚寅). The preface states:

*"The Dao’s essence converges in unity, yet its expressions vary. The sages’ teachings align in sentiment but differ in words. In ancient times, Confucius’ disciples spoke of the Dao of heaven, and thereafter, none could hear it again. Yet the *Yijing*’s six dragons—beginning with ‘Do Not Use’ and ending with ‘Exhausted and Overreaching’—never reveal fortune or misfortune to people. When the nine lines appear, the six dragons have no head, and Confucius praised it: ‘The nine lines manifest the heavenly virtue—it cannot be the leader.’ The *Qian* hexagram’s nine lines reveal the heavenly pattern: firm yet yielding, the Dao of heaven. How does this differ from Laozi? Thus, I say: My understanding of Laozi is like seeing a dragon.*

*The scholar’s greatest flaw is ignorance of the unity between heaven and humanity. Ignorance of this unity makes their discussions of the sages shallow. From ancient times, who has surpassed Laozi in speaking of *ren* (仁), *yi* (义), *li* (礼), and *yue* (乐)? Yet he did not ignore heaven. Who has surpassed Confucius in speaking of *yin-yang* and *yang-yin*? Yet he did not ignore humanity. The sages taught differently, and scholars believed what they spoke; they doubted what they did not. Thus, those who study Laozi disparage Confucianism, and Confucians disparage Laozi. Knowing humanity but not heaven leads to folly; knowing heaven but not humanity leads to deception. How can one judge the sages with such partiality?

*Some say Laozi’s book is about nurturing life. The sage’s Way—internally nourishing the body to ensure longevity and externally ordering affairs to bring harmony—is the same for all sages. Their methods are of one thread. The authors are long gone; their echoes and bones have decayed. Yet their spirit lives on in their words. Xue’s *Laozi’s Collected Explanations* in two volumes is kept at home; I have copied it here.*

*Again, it is said: The Censor Xue, having secluded himself in Meng for a decade, devoted himself to learning. In the year of the Tiger (庚寅), he annotated *Laozi*, titling it *Collected Explanations*. I wrote this preface, and the book was printed. The Master’s intentions were not yet fully realized, so he revised it again in the year of the Hare (丁酉), and it was completed. Upon reading it, I found his interpretations profound, aligning with the Great Middle. Since the Han, no one has understood *Laozi* as decisively as this. Yet the world has no one to recognize him. Who, then, can understand the Master’s annotations?*

*The preface continues: When I was young, I read *Laozi* and thought it was merely the words of an ancient emperor or a noble, speaking of lofty matters beyond common use. Truly, if one secretly applies it, it suffices to cultivate governance and bring order. As I read further, I saw that its teachings harmonize with the sages’ Way without contradiction, applicable to the world. Yet its phrasing is often exaggerated, making it difficult to grasp. The unwise, desiring to believe, resort to supernatural explanations, and thus it was dismissed by Confucians as a book on longevity. His disciples clung to it, causing its words to fade into obscurity. The ancient sages all studied both self-cultivation and governance—some saw it deeply, others superficially, some purely, others mixed. Why must we abandon it entirely, making the world avoid speaking of *Laozi*? His book nearly vanished.*

*I harbored this thought until I met the Chancellor of Wu City, Master Wang Chunfu (王纯父). I asked him: Confucius and Laozi differed in speech—why? Master Wang replied: They both lived in the late Zhou, witnessing the flourishing of culture and eager to return to antiquity. Their words were passionate, and passion often leads to excess. Confucius himself said: ‘If a person lacks *ren*, how can there be *li*? *Li*! *Li*! Is it not about jade and silk?’—meaning that *li* without *ren* is mere empty ritual.*

*Thus, the differences between them are clear.*

The Chancellor of Wu City then said: *"Let us be frugal, and Laozi would reply: ‘Ritual is the thinnest veneer of loyalty and trust, yet the root of chaos. Thus, his words are so vehement that they drift far from Confucius’ measured speech. Therefore, the Master’s teachings are chanted as law for ten thousand generations, while Laozi’s is discarded as something else entirely.*

I kept his words hidden until later, when I served in Shanxi and consulted Master Cao Defang, the Prefect of the Capital. He said: *‘The sages speak of the Dao—just as people name the sky. The Chinese call it *Tian*, while the Xiongnu call it *Chenglei*. Is there truly a difference? Only their words vary. The sky does not know itself, yet people insist on naming it and debating its nature. Thus, the true scholar seeks only the Dao; all else may be forgotten.’*

Ah, how profound his words were! Both these masters delved deeply into Laozi’s thought. Now, examining the *Kaogong* commentary, I find it aligns with the *Yi*’s *Great Transmission*: *‘Though all paths lead to the same end, their ways diverge; though all thoughts converge, their expressions vary. Scholars, accustomed to hearing only differences, fail to see the unity beneath them. They rush to condemn what they do not understand—how could it be just Laozi alone who suffers this fate? Alas, it is difficult to speak of!*

If such a person arises in a hundred generations, they will know it themselves. What need have I for praise or blame? I record these two masters’ words and preface them with this account.*

Li Hongfu engraved Zi You’s commentary in Jinling, and inscribed beneath it:

*‘To eat until full—this is one thing. Southerners eat rice and find it sweet; northerners eat millet and find it sweet. Though one is south and one north, they do not envy each other. Yet if they were to exchange places, they would not reject it either. The Dao in Confucius and Laozi is like rice and millet to the south and north—though one may not envy the other, can it truly be discarded?’*"*

「What then? When one is truly sated, each finds their fill, but when one is truly hungry, there is no rejection. Indeed, I once studied in the north and ate at my host’s home. At first, I knew not its taste.

The cold was severe, and heavy snow fell for three days, cutting off all grain. Seven days passed in hunger, cold, and exhaustion—I gazed upon my host’s table with longing. My host took pity on me, cooked millet, and fed me. I devoured it without pause, unable to discern its nature.

Only after clearing the table did he ask, “Is this not rice and wheat?” I replied, “What strange delight is this?” My host laughed, “This is just millet and barley—no different from what you had before. It is only because you were so hungry that it seemed so fine, and only because it was so fine that you ate so much.”

Now, when you look back, you no longer imagine it as rice and wheat nor as millet and barley. I heard this tale and sighed deeply. If my understanding of the Dao were as desperate as my hunger for food, would Confucius and Laozi hesitate to choose me?

From that moment, I vowed to study the Dao tirelessly, day and night, without rest or food. Later, I obtained *Zi You’s* commentary on *Laozi’s* *Dao De Jing*, as well as *Jiao Ruo’s* commentary—many have expounded on *Laozi*, yet *Zi You* stands supreme.

*Zi You* cited the *Analects* of *Zhu Xi* (宋自明道以后), saying, *“Before the emotions of joy, anger, sorrow, and delight arise, they are called ‘the Middle.’ The Middle before they arise is the mystery of all things.”* Ever since *Zhu Xi*’s *Illumination of the Dao* (明道), each generation has passed down this teaching, instructing their disciples to observe the *qi* of their nature and ask, *“What is its state?”*

*Zi You* alone grasped the subtle meaning within the fragmented texts and broken passages, thus proving his mastery in elucidating *Laozi’s* profound teachings. His five thousand words shine forth like a bright sun—students cannot bear to part with them even for a day.

His commentary reveals the Dao in its entirety, and his intent is fully aligned with *Laozi’s*. He entrusted his meaning to *Zi Zhan*, who also understood it perfectly. Now, five hundred years have passed since *Zi You*, yet here I find this rare and extraordinary work again. Alas, only the truly hungry can attain such wisdom!

In the twelfth month of winter, the second year of *Wàn Lì* (萬曆), *Hongfu* inscribed this preface.

*Master Li Hongfu*, having already engraved *Zi You’s* commentary on *Laozi*, a year later composed his own two-volume commentary. He wrote in the preface:

*“I once read *Han Fei’s* commentary on *Laozi*—though it was not entirely without merit, I could not help but pity him. *Han Fei*, with all his talent, was ultimately executed in *Qin*—yet even in his flawed exposition of *Laozi*, was he not a man of great effort? How could it be said that he accomplished nothing?”*」

Now, the one employs softness and weakness while the other, strength and firmness—this one is bold in daring while that one is bold in not daring. The contrast between the square and the round, ice and fire, is already clear. Yet to claim that *Dao/virtue* and *de* (power) are the ancestral traditions of *Shen Buhai* and *Han Fei*—how can that be?

*Sū Zhīzhān* sought it but could not find it, so he forced an interpretation, saying:

*"The learning of Laozi weighs heavily on non-action and lightly on governing the world and the state. Thus, benevolence is insufficient for love, and ritual is insufficient for reverence. Han Fei obtained the means by which one lightly regards governing the world, and so he became ruthless, harsh, and merciless without hesitation. Alas! If this is so, then how can it be said that one cannot govern the world and the state with it?

Was Laozi’s learning truly like this? Laozi was not one who could govern but did not govern; rather, he was one who did not govern *because* he governed. Thus, those who truly cherish their own bodies do not govern their bodies, and those who truly cherish the world do not govern the world. All that the ancient sage-kings called benevolence, righteousness, ritual, and music were not the means by which they governed. How much less so all the systems of punishments, names, laws, and stratagems!

Therefore, his writings speak only of *Dao/virtue* and *de* (power) and do not speak of benevolence and righteousness—for even if benevolence were without action, it would still not be entirely without action, and righteousness, when put into practice, would be even more so. Thus, his *Way* is:

To take emptiness as the norm,
To take action as the guiding principle,
To take gentle submission and non-contention as the sovereign of all things,
To take delight in war and killing as a necessity,
To regard victory as not beautiful,
To regard retreat as advancement,
To regard defeat as achievement,
To regard fortune as misfortune,
To regard gain as loss,
To regard ignorance as wisdom,
To regard desirelessness as desire,
To regard namelessness as name—
Who would say that non-action is insufficient for governing the world?

The world has yet to know the benefits of non-action.

But then, why does *Han Fei* love it? He says:

*"To follow and achieve is the governance of the emperor-king.
To oppose and yet endure is the art of the Yellow Emperor and Laozi.
To follow and achieve is to govern with a heart that does not endure, enacting policies that do not endure—
Thus, when one follows events with benevolence and applies policies with flexibility, only then can one achieve universal harmony without coercion. Its effects cannot be demanded overnight.

To oppose and yet endure is to make the desirable unseen—
Thus, there is no governance that is not achieved, yet no heart can be discerned in its workings;
No subject is unsettled, yet no virtue can be praised in it—
Such is all there is to it.

This is the most easy, most subtle *Way*, yet it is what all those who seek quick results and profit revere.
But those who seek profit and results wish to emulate it and yet cannot—
Thus, they cannot endure desirelessness but endure killing;
They cannot endure self-restraint but endure inflicting it on others;
They cannot endure endurance but endure not enduring.

Scholars, failing to discern its source, doubt its origin and say, ‘The calamity of *Dao/virtue* is that it later became *Shen Buhai* and *Han Fei*.’

If this is so, then indeed *Dao/virtue* later became *Shen Buhai* and *Han Fei*.
Yet why not say that the calamity of benevolence and righteousness was fratricide and regicide?

Many schools of learning have existed since antiquity—
After one or two transmissions, they are lost, and their harm is incalculable. How few are there?

Alone, Laozi?

From this perspective, it can be said that *Shen Buhai* and *Han Fei* originally followed the intent of *Dao/virtue*—how can this not be granted?

My nature is rigid, and my *qi* suffers from excessive firmness, unable to restrain itself.
I enjoy reading *Han Fei’s* works, yet I dare not again let the *Dao/virtue* tradition bring about calamity.
But because of *Dao/virtue*, I deeply appreciate it and have composed this commentary and preface to reflect on my own words regarding *Dao/virtue*.

The gentleman’s name was *Li Zàifáng*, a native of *Wēnlíng*. He held office as the Prefect of *Yà’ān* before retiring.

「Among the ancient books that have come down to the ages and been altered by men, there are many—but none more so than Laozi. In the Kaiyuan annotation, it is explicitly stated that I alone differ from others in valuing "seeking food from the mother" (i.e., nourishment from the Dao/Way) over the two characters "there is no seeking." The additions made by later scholars are reckless and do not reflect the original intent of Laozi’s text. How numerous are these alterations?

Sima Qian wrote that Laozi’s book contained over five thousand words, but this was merely an approximation. Some have gone so far as to arbitrarily delete auxiliary words just to fit the five thousand count—this is the misfortune caused by Sima Qian’s single remark.

Master Xue Jun (采氏) compiled *Laozi’s* *Ji* (Collection) *and Jie* (Exegesis), separately creating a section titled *Kǎo Yì* (Examination of Differences) appended to it. However, the sources he consulted were only about ten in number. I have seen many more scrolls and volumes, with numerous discrepancies. What he arranged for me is already recorded in the orthodox text, while the rest he attached to the end of the volume, still calling it *Kǎo Yì*. Let those who love antiquity verify this.

guard against losing your treasure.

The world cannot know, cannot act.

thus, I am honored.

*[One version reads "wearing coarse hemp" (披褐)]*
*[One version appends "and" (而) after "cloth" (褐)]*

Above, there is sickness.
*[Ancient texts read "Above, sickness!" (尚矣)]*

*[Han Fei reads "The Sage’s lack of sickness is because they do not have sickness—thus, no sickness" (圣人之不病也以其不病是以无病也)]*
thus, they are not sick.

Great awe has arrived.
*[One version reads "then great awe has arrived" (则大威至)]*

*[One version reads "do not be familiar" (无狎)]*

*[Wu Fangqing reads "only the unfamiliar" (夫唯不狎)]*

These two—
*[One version appends "know" (知) before "these"]*
*[One version is incorrect (非)]*
are subtle.

*[One version appends "constantly" (常) after "people"]*

*[Ancient texts append "thus" (也) after "dares"]*
*[One version reads "could" (岂) instead of "if I can" (吾得)]*
—to take my place as executioner?
*[One version reads "husband" (夫) instead of "to" (而)]*
This is like substituting for the master carpenter to hew—
*[One version appends "it is said" (谓) after "this"]*
few will avoid injuring their hands.
*[One version reads "few have" (希有) instead of "few" (希)]*
*[One version omits "their" (其)]*

The people’s hunger—
*[Ancient texts append "thus" (者) after "hunger"]*
it is because taxes are too heavy.
*[One version omits "thus" (也) after "heavy"]*

*[One version reads "because of their excessive seeking of life" (以其上求生之厚)]*

*[One version appends "thus" (夫) before "only"]*
*[One version appends "noble" (贵) after "life" (生)]*

Grass and trees,
*[One version prefaces with "all things" (万物)]*

*[One version reads "weak" (弱) instead of "fragile" (脆)]*
*[Ancient texts append "thus" (也) after "fragile"]*
strong arms,
*[Ancient texts append "thus" (者) after "arms"]*

*[One version reads "give it to" (与之)]*

*[Ancient texts read "who can reduce excess to nourish the insufficient in the world? Only those of the Dao, is it not so?" (孰能损有余而奉不足于天下者其唯有道者乎)]*

*[One version reads "when the work is done, they do not reside" (功成不处)]*

*[One version omits "thus" (耶)]*

*[One version reads "nothing is as soft and weak as water" (天下柔弱莫过于水)]*

*[One version reads "prevails" (胜) instead of "overcome" (先)]*

*[One version omits "thus" (以)]*

the weak overcomes the strong.
*[One version appends "thus" (故) before "no one"]*

yet no one can act upon it.
*[Ancient texts read "yet no one can act upon it" (而莫之能行)]*

*[One version reads "therefore" (是以)]*
*[Ancient texts append "thus" (之言)]*

*[Ancient texts append "thus" (也) after "inverted"]*

Let the people possess tenfold or hundredfold implements,

Let them find their food delightful,
their customs secure,
their occupations joyous.
Let their music resound,

The virtuous do not argue;
those who argue are not virtuous.
Do not accumulate—
the Dao of Heaven.

The Imperially Commissioned *Complete Library of the Four Treasuries*
*Masters Section, Fourteenth Division*
*Wings of Laozi*
*Daoist School*
*Abstract*

We, your ministers, respectfully note: *Wings of Laozi* in three juan was compiled by Jiao Hong of the Ming dynasty. Hong’s *Easy Explanation of the Book of Changes* has already been recorded. This work gathers sixty-four exegetes from Han Fei onward who interpreted *Laozi*, appending Hong’s own notes to form sixty-five entries. Each entry distills the finest insights into a single compilation. Where passages remain intact from beginning to end, forming complete sections, the work follows the example of Li Dingzuo’s *Collected Explications of the Zhou Changes*, marking each with the commentator’s name and placing it after the original chapter. For glosses on pronunciation, meaning, or single words and phrases, it adopts Pei Yin’s *Collected Explications of the Records of the Grand Historian*, weaving them into the text and appending them to the final sentence of the original chapter. The *Upper* and *Lower* chapters each occupy one juan, while the *Appendices* and *Textual Variants* form another, totaling three juan. The work does not impose the titles *Dao Classic* or *Virtue Classic*, nor does it arbitrarily assign chapter names. Its editorial principles are particularly aligned with those of ancient works. Most of the selected commentaries are drawn from the *Daoist Canon*, many of which are not commonly circulated in the world. Hong’s selections are notably precise and judicious, his primary aim being to elucidate the original words and clarify the principles of purity and naturalness. For instance, while figures like Ge Changgeng often conflated Daoist alchemical practices with Chan Buddhist repartee, though their names are listed, their interpretations are largely excluded. Among the various commentaries, the work is both erudite and reasoned. This is because Hong’s scholarship in the teachings of the Two Schools (Daoism and Buddhism) was profound, surpassing even his grasp of Confucianism. Thus, his explanations of Confucian principles often stray into vagueness, while his exegesis of the Two Schools’ doctrines demonstrates discernment and originality.

Respectfully submitted for imperial review in the second month of the forty-fifth year of the Qianlong reign.

Minister Ji Yun
Minister Lu Xixiong
Minister Sun Shiyi

*Chief Collator:*

*Laozi* is a book that illuminates the Dao. So too did Wang Zhen of the Tang dynasty...

chunks.translated_text:
Those who go so far as to claim it was composed as a treatise on warfare—could it be that even the words on fine soldiers and skillful battle have somehow inspired them? I say: Laozi does not speak of warfare. It illuminates the attainment of suppleness. Of all things under heaven that delight in strength, none surpasses warfare, and yet even warfare is made to yield through suppleness. From this, one may infer that where there is no suppleness, there is no Dao. Suppleness is the opposite of rigidity. The Dao is present in all things, yet why does it uniquely favor suppleness and treat rigidity as secondary?

I say: Laozi does not speak of suppleness. It illuminates non-action. Suppleness is not the Dao itself, but it approaches non-action. Rigidity is not outside the Dao, but it distances itself from non-action. Thus, by seeking through suppleness, non-action may be guarded. That which is non-existent cannot but have existence, just as suppleness cannot be without rigidity. Yet when one establishes it upon the constancy of non-being and being, the world’s benevolence, righteousness, sageliness, and wisdom do not cease to be discarded. This is merely another case of elevating one while abolishing the hundred.

I say: Laozi does not speak of the non-existence of non-being. It illuminates the non-being of existence. The non-existence of non-being is to abandon existence in pursuit of non-being—its name is "severance." The non-being of existence is to use existence to verify non-being—its teaching is "returning to the root." If all things return to their roots, then though the ten thousand beings flourish together, they ultimately cannot be called "existent." This is the ultimate of attaining emptiness and maintaining quiescence.

Scholars know the vessel but not the Dao, hence the *Yi* clarifies the Dao through the vessel. They see form but not emptiness, hence Buddhism clarifies emptiness through form. They grasp being but not non-being, hence Laozi clarifies non-being through being. If one truly understands that being is non-being, then in non-action, affairs are not acted upon, yet nothing is left undone, and nothing can obstruct it. What, then, is there to discard?

Thus it is said: *Laozi* is a book that illuminates the Dao. I was once fond of rigidity and forceful conduct, reading *Laozi* as if feeding through the ears—no different from not having read it at all. At twenty-three, I heard the teachings of masters and friends and gradually turned my mind to learning, though I found it difficult to enter. There were those who guided me with what they called "luminous clarity," and I rejoiced as if it resonated within. Reflecting upon it in my heart was like a horse with bit and bridle, or a door with hinge and pivot. Comparing it with the teachings of recent Confucians was like tallying pieces that fit perfectly.

Believing the Dao to lie therein, I looked back upon twenty years—wherever I turned, obstacles arose. Where there were obstacles, there were doubts. Examining antiquity, I found much that clashed; where there was clash, there was contradiction. Never for a moment did this leave my thoughts.

In recent years, worn down by hardship and long illness, in the stillness of convalescence, I suddenly awoke alone and sighed deeply, saying: In the past, I never failed to reject the discriminating mind, yet sometimes sought to extinguish it in pursuit of quiescence. I never failed to prize the mindless state, yet did not know that the original mind is naturally without knowing. I yearned for purity and stillness, yet did not know that the stainless is not pure. I knew of the true self, yet did not know that where there is no thing, there is no self. All this was led astray by the teachings of others.

From then on, as I pursued my views, they vanished without a trace, and I, too, fortunately became a man of non-action. At that time, my friend Zhai Defo, who was fond of discussing *Laozi*, would occasionally bring it up to test me. I responded with my recent insights, and Defo never failed to applaud them. He urged me to write an exposition, so I gathered my family’s old copies of *Laozi* along with those collected in the Daoist Canon, reading through them all—sixty-four versions in total. How vast their words! Among them, though statements that betray the Dao and depart from the classics were not uncommon, those that accorded were not few.

Reciting and chanting in cycles, I sighed deeply—ah! The five thousand words of *Laozi* are sometimes said to encompass the entire book of Rongchengzi. *Liezi* also claims that the "Valley Spirit" chapter was not written by the Yellow Emperor, hence the saying: "Transmitting but not creating, trusting and cherishing antiquity, I compare myself to Lao Peng." The sages of old could illuminate the Dao without it all necessarily originating from themselves. How much less, then, could I—whose understanding of this matter is but a fraction of a hair’s tip, not even one ten-thousandth—presume to add to it?

Thus, I set aside my own composition and instead gathered the commentaries of earlier scholars, arranging and compiling them into a single volume, with a few superficial insights of my own appended. Defo, meanwhile, was still in the midst of explicating the *Yinfu Jing* and had not yet completed it. When he finishes, we shall present both works together to scholars. For now, I merely record this preface and keep it in my home.

Written in the winter of the *dinghai* year of the Wanli era by Jiao Hong, styled Ruohou.

chunks.translated_text:
The Dao that can be spoken is not the constant Dao;
The name that can be named is not the constant name.
Nameless, it is the beginning of Heaven and Earth;
Named, it is the mother of the myriad things.
Thus, constantly without desire, one observes its mystery;
Constantly with desire, one observes its manifestations.
These two emerge together yet differ in name—
Together they are called the profound.
Profound and ever more profound:
The gateway to all mysteries.

[The "can be spoken" is like ritual—Dao is not vainly spoken.
"Constant" means enduring and unchanging.
"Mother" signifies that things arise from it.
"Desire" is like the desires of human nature; "之欲" means intention or emotion.
"Manifestations" (徼) are the apertures through which things emerge, or their boundaries, their returns.
Chen Jingyuan says: "At the edge of the great Dao are small paths called *jiao*."
Ding Yidong says: "The nameless is the beginning of Heaven and Earth; the named is the mother of the myriad things." Some read this as "nameless and named," while others read it as "nonbeing and being." Yet Laozi also says, "The Dao is constantly nameless; only when the beginning is instituted does it have a name"—how then can it be read as "nonbeing and being"?
Those who read it as "constantly without, constantly with" and those who read it as "without desire, with desire"—Zhuangzi says, "Establish it in the constant of nonbeing and being," directly pointing to Laozi’s words, so the punctuation of "constantly without, constantly with" seems correct. Yet Laozi also says, "Constantly without desire, it can be named as small"—this cannot be used as evidence from Zhuangzi. Laozi should be read as Laozi.]

Cheng Ju’s Discourse:
The Dao that can be spoken is for regulating conduct;
The name that can be named is for establishing speech.
As for the constant Dao that cannot be spoken,
The constant name that cannot be named—
The sage does not dare to reveal it to others.
Not that it is concealed in secrecy and withheld,
But that it cannot be shown to others.

chunks.translated_text:
Thus, the sages of the Western Regions manifest their teachings through three vehicles and expound them into twelve divisions, calling them "teachings." Yet what is transmitted beyond these teachings is precisely that which cannot be spoken and cannot be named. The sages of China—from the lineage of Tang, Yu, Xia, Wen, and Wu—codified the texts of the *Odes*, *Documents*, rites, and music, calling them "classics." Yet what their words tread like footprints that are not the path itself is also that which cannot be spoken and cannot be named. Therefore, Laozi composed his five-thousand-character text to reveal it to the world and guide later generations, not retreating into the obscurity of the Dao to hoard it for himself. Thus, the opening of his words speaks of the Dao that can be spoken and the name that can be named—these are what the five-thousand-character text encompasses. As for what the sages do not transmit, it cannot be put into words.

Su Ziyou’s commentary:
All is the Dao, yet what can be spoken of it cannot be constant. Only what cannot be spoken of is truly constant. Consider benevolence, righteousness, propriety, and wisdom—these are the Dao that can be spoken. Yet benevolence cannot become righteousness, nor can propriety become wisdom; what can be spoken of is thus not constant. Only what cannot be spoken of remains in benevolence as benevolence, in righteousness as righteousness, and so too with propriety and wisdom—these are all inconstant, while the Dao remains unchanging. Such is the constancy of what cannot be spoken. If the Dao cannot be spoken, how much less can it be named? All names belong to what can be spoken. Once a name is established, the differences between round and square, crooked and straight cannot be constant. Before names took form, there were heaven and earth; once heaven and earth were established, names began. From the dissemination of names arose the myriad things, and with the flourishing of the myriad things, names became innumerable. Thus, the nameless is the essence of the Dao, while the named is its function. The sage embodies the Dao to function in the world, entering into the realm of multiplicity while remaining in the constant of nonbeing to observe its subtleties. Embodying the utmost nonbeing while abiding in the constant of being, he observes its manifestations. Yet if one acts within manifestations without knowing the subtleties, one remains coarse and unspiritual; if one dwells in subtleties without knowing the manifestations, one becomes refined but unchanging. In terms of form, being and nonbeing are indeed two—how can one know that nonbeing transforms into being and being returns to nonbeing, never not unified? Though their names differ, their root is one. To know the unity of the root is to attain the profound. Whatever is boundless and without limit must be profound in color; thus, Laozi often used "profound" to signify the ultimate. To speak of the profound is to reach it, yet the mind that clings to the profound still remains. Profound upon profound—only then is it exhausted, beyond further addition. This is the source from which all subtleties arise.

Lǚ Jifu annotates:
All the Ways under heaven that can be spoken of are indeed the Dao, yet there are times when they verge on peril—such are not the constant Dao. All the names under heaven that can be named are indeed names, yet there are times when they depart—such are not the constant names. The myriad things flourish and flourish, each returning to its root, yet they know it not. Stillness is called "returning to destiny"; returning to destiny is called "constancy." To be constant is to attain the Dao. When one reaches constancy, the mind congeals, form dissolves, and self and other are all forgotten. Who then knows what can be spoken as Dao or named as name? Thus, the constant Dao is inherently unspeakable. Therefore it is said: "The Dao buries itself in long obscurity, never imperiled." The constant name is inherently unnameable. Therefore it is said: "From ancient times to now, its name does not depart." Not imperiled, not departed—this is called the constant Dao. The constant nonbeing of name—this nonbeing is the Dao, the origin from which heaven and earth themselves arise. Thus it is said: "Nameless, it is the beginning of heaven and earth." In the Great Beginning, there was nonbeing; there was no nonbeing, no name. When there was no nonbeing, even "one" could not be attained. When there was no name, this was the arising of the one. There was one, yet no form had appeared. To call it "one" is already to have a name, though no form yet exists. The name "one" and that which names it make two; two and one make three. From this, the myriad things in profusion arise. Thus it is said: "The named is the mother of the myriad things." To know constancy is called "clarity"; clarity sees all without obstruction. Only constancy allows one to observe: when there is no desire, one purifies and polishes the profound mirror, leaving no flaw in this observation of the subtle. Thus it is said: "Constantly without desire, one may name it the small." When there is desire, the myriad things arise together in profusion; in this, one observes their manifestations. Thus it is said: "The myriad things all return to it, yet they know not their master—one may name it the great." Only the small reveals the subtle; only the great reveals the manifest. These two emerge from the same source, yet their names differ—nothing more. Though their names differ, their reality has never differed. Whether in desire or the absence of desire, their source cannot be sought. If it cannot be sought, then their source is the same. Thus it is called "profound." Is the color of profundity the same whether black or red? One. Is the color of heaven the same whether in yin or yang? One. Do names arise from the profound in the same way, whether in desire or its absence? One. They are the same.

chunks.original_text: 一固妙矣 然妙乎 一矣 未妙乎 多也 妙乎 我矣 未妙乎 物也 之又则同者亦不可得同者不可得则一之与多我之与物莫不皆妙也 万物之所以妙出于此而已故曰之又众妙之门】 李息斋注【常者不变之谓也 物有变而道无变物之变至于念念迁谢俯仰之间未尝少停至所谓道则无始无终天地有尽而此道无尽是之谓常常之为道不可行而至不可名而得使其可行即非常道使其可名即非常名自未始有天地而真常之理已具于无名之初故无名为天地之始及天地既判高下之名生万物自是而滋故可以名者物之母也 圣人体真常之道以出入于有无之间故妙者大道也 无也 徼者小道也 有也 吾欲观其妙则与妙同入而归于无吾欲观其徼则与徼同出而游于有妙即徼徼即妙有即空空即有其本同其末异故同谓之不独此也 至于之又即能使众徼之间无非众妙是谓众妙之门言其于徼妙有无之间无拣择而皆妙也 】 笔乘【徼读如边徼之徼言物之尽处也 晏子曰徼也 者德之归也 列子曰死者德之徼皆指尽处而言盖无之为无不待言已方其有欲之时人皆执以为有然有欲必有尽及其尽也 极而无所更往必复归于无斯与妙何以异哉 故曰此两者同谓之虽然老子亦不得已为未悟者言耳 实非舍有以求无也 苟其舍有以求无则是有外更有无安得为无盖当其有时实未尝有此乃真无也 故不灭色以为空色即空不事以为空事即空不然其所谓无者为对有之无而所谓有者为对无之有亦恶得谓之常无常有哉 噫安得知常者而与之一论此】 天下皆知美之为美斯恶已皆知善之为善斯不善已故有无相生难易相成长短相形高下相倾声音相和前后相随是以圣人处无为之事行不言之敎万物作焉而不辞生而不有为而不恃功成而不居夫唯不居是以不去【倾不平也生成形倾和随皆以喻美恶善不善相形而有处上声夫音符】 陆希声注【夫人之所谓美恶皆生于情以适情为美逆情为恶以至善不善亦然然所美者未必美所恶者未必恶所善者未必善所不善者未必不善如此者何情使然也 夫人之性大同而其情则异以殊异之情外感于物是以好恶相缪美恶无主将何以正之哉 在乎 复性而已何则情之所生必由于性故圣人化情复性而至乎 大同所谓有无之相生者情性也 情性之相因犹难易之相成也 夫为治者以情化性则难成以性正情则易成所谓长短之相形者美恶也 美恶之相夺犹高下之相倾也 所谓声音之相和者善不善也 善不善之相资犹先后之相随也 于乎 世之多故由此六者天下所以不治万物莫得遂性圣人将复其性先化其情善者固已善不善者吾亦因而善之使善信者固已信不信者吾亦因而信之使信故用无弃物敎无弃人使在物无恶在人无不善而天下不治者未之有也 易曰其道甚大百物不废此之谓也 是以圣人体无名则无为而事自定用有名则不言而敎自行使万物各遂其性若无使之然者如天地之生物而不有其用如百工之为器而不恃其成如四时之成岁而不居其所夫惟如此是以其道可常其名不去也 】苏注【天下以形名言美恶其所谓美且善者岂信美且善哉 彼不知有无长短难易高下声音前后之相生相夺皆非其正也 方且自以为长而有长于我者临之斯则短矣 方且自以为前而有前于我者先之斯则后矣 苟从其所美而信之则失之远矣 当事而为无为之之心当敎而言无言之之意夫是以出于长短之度离于先后之数非美非恶非善非不善而天下何足以知之万物为我作而我无所辞我生之为之而未尝有未尝恃至于成功亦未尝以自居也

One is indeed wondrous—yet is it wondrous only as One? Is it not also wondrous as Many? Is it wondrous only as the self? Is it not also wondrous as things? When the profound is pursued to the utmost profundity, even sameness cannot be found. If sameness cannot be found, then neither One nor Many, neither self nor things—all are wondrous without exception. The wondrousness of the myriad things arises from this alone. Thus it is said: "The profound pursued to the utmost profundity is the gateway to all wonders."

Li Xizhai’s Commentary:
"Constant" means unchanging. Things change, but the Dao does not. The changes of things extend to the fleeting of thoughts and the passing of moments, never pausing for even an instant. Yet what is called the Dao has no beginning and no end; heaven and earth may perish, but this Dao does not—this is what is meant by "constant." As the constant Dao, it cannot be traversed to its end, nor can it be named to be attained. If it could be traversed, it would not be the constant Dao; if it could be named, it would not be the constant name. Before the beginning of heaven and earth, the principle of true constancy was already present in the nameless origin. Thus, the nameless is the beginning of heaven and earth. Once heaven and earth were divided, names arose for high and low, and the myriad things multiplied from this point onward. Thus, what can be named is the mother of things.

The sage embodies the Dao of true constancy, moving between being and non-being. The wondrous is the great Dao—non-being. The manifest is the lesser Dao—being. If I wish to observe the wondrous, I enter into wondrousness and return to non-being. If I wish to observe the manifest, I emerge with manifestation and wander in being. The wondrous is the manifest; the manifest is the wondrous. Being is emptiness; emptiness is being. Their root is the same, though their branches differ. Thus, they are both called "profound." And not only this: when the profound is pursued to the utmost profundity, it enables all manifestations to be nothing but wonders. This is called "the gateway to all wonders," for within manifestation and wondrousness, being and non-being, there is no distinction—all are wondrous.

*Bishu*:
The character *jiao* (徼) is read like the *jiao* in "frontier" (边徼), referring to the furthest extent of things. Yanzi said, "Manifestation is the return of virtue." Liezi said, "Death is the furthest extent of virtue." Both refer to the point of exhaustion. When there is non-being, nothing remains to be said. Yet when desire arises, people cling to being as if it were real. But desire must come to an end, and when it is exhausted, having reached its limit with nowhere else to go, it must return to non-being. How is this different from wondrousness? Thus it is said: "These two are called the same profound." Nevertheless, Laozi spoke thus out of necessity for those who have not yet awakened. In truth, he did not advocate abandoning being to seek non-being. If one were to abandon being to seek non-being, then beyond being there would be non-being—how could this be true non-being? When being is present, it has never truly been being—this is genuine non-being. Thus, form is not destroyed to become emptiness; form is emptiness. Affairs are not negated to become emptiness; affairs are emptiness. Otherwise, the so-called non-being would be non-being in opposition to being, and the so-called being would be being in opposition to non-being. How could this be called constant non-being or constant being? Alas, how can one who does not know the constant engage in discussion of this?

When all under heaven know beauty as beauty, ugliness is already present. When all know goodness as goodness, non-goodness is already present. Thus, being and non-being give rise to each other; difficulty and ease complete each other; long and short shape each other; high and low incline toward each other; sound and voice harmonize with each other; front and back follow one another. Therefore, the sage abides in non-action and practices wordless teaching. The myriad things arise, yet he does not reject them; he gives life, yet does not possess; he acts, yet does not rely on it; he accomplishes, yet does not dwell in it. It is precisely because he does not dwell that it does not depart.

Lu Xisheng’s Commentary:
What people call beauty and ugliness arise from emotion: what conforms to emotion is beauty, what opposes it is ugliness. The same applies to goodness and non-goodness. Yet what is deemed beautiful is not necessarily beautiful; what is deemed ugly is not necessarily ugly; what is deemed good is not necessarily good; what is deemed non-good is not necessarily non-good. Why is this? Emotion is the cause. Human nature is fundamentally the same, but emotions differ. When these differing emotions are externally affected by things, likes and dislikes become entangled, and beauty and ugliness have no fixed standard. How can this be corrected? It lies in returning to nature. Why? The arising of emotion must originate from nature. Thus, the sage transforms emotion to return to nature, reaching great unity. What is called "being and non-being giving rise to each other" refers to emotion and nature. The mutual dependence of emotion and nature is like the mutual completion of difficulty and ease. Those who govern by using emotion to transform nature find it difficult to succeed; those who use nature to correct emotion find it easy. What is called "long and short shaping each other" refers to beauty and ugliness. The competition between beauty and ugliness is like the inclination of high and low. What is called "sound and voice harmonizing with each other" refers to goodness and non-goodness. The mutual reliance of goodness and non-goodness is like the following of front and back. Alas, the world’s many troubles arise from these six. This is why the world is not at peace, and the myriad things cannot fulfill their nature. The sage, wishing to restore their nature, first transforms their emotions. Those who are already good are confirmed in their goodness; those who are not good are also led to goodness, so that all become good. Those who are already trustworthy are confirmed in their trust; those who are not trustworthy are also led to trust, so that all become trustworthy. Thus, nothing is discarded in things, and no one is abandoned in teaching. When things have no ugliness and people have no non-goodness, an ungoverned world has never existed. The *Yijing* says: "Its Dao is vast, and the hundred things are not abandoned." This is what it means.

Therefore, the sage embodies the nameless and thus acts without action, and affairs settle themselves. He employs the named and thus teaches without words, and instruction proceeds on its own. He enables the myriad things to fulfill their nature as if nothing had caused it—like heaven and earth giving life to things without possessing them, like the hundred craftsmen making tools without relying on them, like the four seasons completing the year without dwelling in it. Only in this way can his Dao be constant and his name not depart.

Su’s Commentary:
All under heaven speak of beauty and ugliness in terms of form and name. What they call beautiful and good—are these truly beautiful and good? They do not know that being and non-being, long and short, difficulty and ease, high and low, sound and voice, front and back—all arise and compete with one another, and none are in their true state. When one takes oneself to be long, and another longer appears, one becomes short. When one takes oneself to be ahead, and another appears before, one becomes behind. If one follows what is deemed beautiful and trusts it, one strays far from the truth. When acting, one should have the mind of non-action; when teaching, one should have the intention of wordless instruction. Only thus can one transcend the measures of long and short, depart from the calculations of front and back—neither beautiful nor ugly, neither good nor non-good. How could all under heaven know this? The myriad things act for me, yet I do not reject them; I give life to them, yet do not possess them; I act, yet do not rely on it; I accomplish, yet do not dwell in it.

Is the color of profundity the same whether black or red? One. Is the color of heaven the same whether in yin or yang? One. Do names arise from the profound in the same way, whether in desire or its absence? One. They are the same.
